title: Ticket #821: HDFS_ALLOW/DENY ignore ALLOW/DENY when choosing default
description:
HDFS_ALLOW/DENY use HOSTALLOW_WRITE/HOSTDENY_WRITE and HOSTALLOW_READ/HOSTDENY_READ when choosing a default. The settings for ALLOW_READ/DENY_READ and ALLOW_WRITE/DENY_WRITE should also be included, because this is how Condor works internally: HOSTALLOW_* and ALLOW_* lists are added together, as are HOSTDENY_* and DENY_*.

Another question is what the hadoop code will make of the full Condor authorization syntax, which may include the authenticated user name in addition to a hostname (username@domain/hostname). Even HOSTALLOW/HOSTDENY settings can contain such entries. Will the hadoop code simply ignore them, or will it get confused by them?
check_ins:
2009-Oct-16 15:34   Check-in [16108]: Have the Windows installer use the ALLOW/DENY configuration parameters instead of the old HOSTALLOW/HOSTDENY options. This is to keep up with the change in the default configuration file made by Dan Bradley. Ticket #821. (By Ziliang Guo )
2009-Oct-08 11:53   Check-in [15948]: Converted HOSTALLOW/HOSTDENY to ALLOW/DENY in all examples. For years, the manual has claimed that HOSTALLOW/HOSTDENY are the old deprecated way to do things. This makes it confusing when people try to follow examples in the manual and their new ALLOW/DENY settings get merged with the default config [...] (By Dan Bradley )
